citation.article-title: Gemmata obscuriglobus, a new genus and species of the budding bacteria

p.s: Description of Gemmata obscuriglobus sp. nov
Gemmata obscuriglobus (L. adj. obscurus meaning dark and L.n. globus meaning a sphere)
Spherical to pear-shaped cells, (1.4-3.0) x (1.4-3.0) μm, which form new cells by budding through a narrow bud attachment site.
Cells contain a phase-dark inclusion which contains fibrillar nuclear material.
The cell wall has a structure typical of gram-negative cells and the gram stain is negative.
A discrete holdfast is not produced and attachment to glass surfaces appears to be effected by secreted slime from a broad area on the cell.
Newly formed buds are motile by multitrichous flagella.
After swarming cells become attached to surfaces.
Generation time on Staley's maintenance medium at 24°C is about 13 h.

Glucose, galactose, mannose, xylose, ribose, rhamnose, melezitose, salicin and starch are utilized as carbon sources but not fructose, pyruvate, lactate, acetate, tartrate, propionate, phthalate, glycerol, mannitol, ethanol, methanol, adonitol or a large number of amino acids.
The temperature range for growth is 16.0° to 35.0°C The mol% G+C of the DNA is 64.4 ± 1.0.
